text.p: These are the leading stories in the Namibian press on Tuesday.
Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.

- The Namibian government is apparently going ahead with the planned purchase of around 800 General Motors (GM) vehicles at an estimated cost of N$136 million. Ths signing of an agreement between the Ministry of Works, Transport and Communication and Barden International, which has been granted fleet and retail dealer status by GM is expected tomorrow. The setting up of a N$33 million assembly plant is part of the deal.

- Around 80 employees of the Ministry of Environment and Tourism demonstrated peacefully in front of Parliament, calling for the speeding up of affirmative action within the tourism sector. They also called for the Namibia Wildlife Resorts Company Bill, which aims at commercialisation of nature resorts to be scrapped.
- Employees working at the rest camps of the Ministry of Environment and Tourism are taking part in strike action for affirmative action and better training.
